conclusion: Take the axis O as origin of gravitational potential energy.
Initial position: the rod is horizontal, so the ball is at the same level as O, h₀ = 0.
Highest position P: the rod is vertical, therefore the ball is L above O, h = L.
Kinetic–potential relation: ½ m v₀² = ½ m v_P² + m g L
Insert the data: m = 1 kg, v₀ = 4 m/s, g = 10 m/s², L = 0.50 m
Solve: 8 = ½ v_P² + 5, ½ v_P² = 3, v_P² = 6, v_P = √6 ≈ 2.45 m/s
The velocity at P is tangential to the circle, i.e. horizontal to the right.
Choose the downward direction (toward O) as positive radial direction.
Forces on the ball at P: Weight mg (downward), Force exerted by the rod on the ball (T) downward toward O.
Centripetal requirement: mg + T = m v_P² / L
Compute T: m v_P² / L = (1)(6)/(0.50) = 12 N
Calculate T: T = 12 N – mg = 12 N – 10 N = 2 N
Thus the rod pulls the ball downward with a force of 2 N.
By Newton’s third law the ball exerts on the rod an equal force in the opposite direction: magnitude: 2 N, direction: upward along the rod.
The small ball exerts a 2-newton force on the light rod, directed upward along the rod.
